questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect concerning insight?

options.label: B
options.text: Level 1 is a complete denial of illness

options.label: C
options.text: Level 3 is awareness of being sick but blaming it on external factors

options.label: D
options.text: Insight is a degree of personal awareness and understanding of illness

questions.correct_answer: A. Insight is present in psychosis.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Insight is present in psychosis. It is the degree of personal awareness and understanding of illness. Levels of insight: Complete denial of illness Slight awareness of being sick and needing help but denying it at the same time Awareness of being sick but blaming it on others , on external factors , on medical or unknown organic factors. Intellectual insight : Admission of illness and recognition that symptoms or failures in social adjustment are due to irrational feelings or disturbances, without applying that knowledge to future experiences True emotional insight : Emotional awareness of the motives and feelings within, of the underlying meaning of symptoms; does the awareness lead to changes in personality and future behavior; openness to new ideas and concepts about self and the important persons in his or her life.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male student comes with a two-month history of repeated thoughts and anxiety that he is going to be harmed by someone on the street, and he stopped going to college because of this fear. He denies auditory, visual, or tactile hallucinations. On MSE, he is alert and oriented and shows a full range of effects. Thought processes and speech are organized. Urine toxicology screening is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Delusional disorder A delusional disorder is diagnosed when the patient has one or more delusions that last ≥ 1 month and are not the result of schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, or substance abuse . Unlike other psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia or schizophreniform disorder, a delusional disorder does not result in significant functional impairment .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A . Patients with a schizophreniform disorder/Schizophrenia usually have bizarre delusions (i.e., clearly implausible, not derived from ordinary life experiences, and/or not understandable) and cause significant functional impairment . Moreover, other features such as auditory hallucinations, disorganized speech, a flattened affect, and/or catatonia are seen with schizophreniform disorder. Option: C. A patient with a schizotypal personality disorder may be suspicious, anxious, and have ideas of reference (e.g., witnessing a traffic accident makes the patient believe that this event has a personal significance). However, the anxiety in schizotypal personality disorder is usually provoked by social interactions rather than a fear of bodily harm. Moreover, other features of this personality disorder such as few friends, oddly dressed appearance, magical beliefs that are inconsistent with cultural norms, and/or a restricted affect are not present in this patient. Option: D . A negative urine TOX screen makes substance abuse less likely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought by his father because of a change in his personality over the past 7 months, where his son has become increasingly withdrawn, not answering any phone calls or visiting his family and friends. The patient says that he cannot leave the house because aliens are watching him and “stealing his thoughts”. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schizophrenia Schizophrenia tends to present initially with a prodrome of negative symptoms (e.g., social withdrawal as in this case) that precedes the positive psychotic symptoms , such as delusions (e.g., bizarre thoughts of aliens watching him) and disorganized speech as seen in this patient. The diagnosis also requires signs of illness must persist for at least 6 months .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A . Schizophreniform disorder is an important differential diagnosis as the symptoms are the same as in this patient. But schizophreniform disorder can only be diagnosed if the symptoms have not been present for longer than 6 months . This patient's symptoms began 7 months ago. Option: C. Although paranoid personality disorder is also characterized by excessive suspicions and paranoia, such suspicion derives from a distrust of others rather than long-standing bizarre delusions such as aliens stealing thoughts. Additionally, personality disorders are stable over time , whereas this patient's symptoms started only 7 months ago. Personality disorders start in adolescence. Option: D. Although a brief psychotic disorder can cause symptoms similar to those seen in this patient, it can only be diagnosed if symptoms persist for > 1 day but ≤ 1 month . This patient's symptoms started 7 months ago.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy has recurrent intrusive thoughts which he perceives to be senseless and involuntary. He starts believing these thoughts are being inserted by his family members though these are his thoughts. Which of the following diagnoses must be considered apart from OCD in the future?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schizophrenia A symptom suggesting schizophrenia is thought insertion, which is an important symptom during the prodrome of psychosis. The prodrome of psychosis may present with obsessional symptoms. Often it is difficult to differentiate OCD from schizophrenia in such presentations. But the useful pointers are: Ego-dystonic nature of obsessions may not be prominent in psychosis The insight that the thoughts are one’s own may not be seen in psychosis Resistance to the obsessions may be conspicuously absent; and The content of obsessions may be bizarre , instead of the usual themes of safety, contamination, sex, violence, religion, etc.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: B . Depression- DSM-5 Criteria to diagnose depression : Two or more episodes of major depression diagnosed by the following: Five or more of the following symptoms have been present most of the time for at least 2 weeks: Depressed mood Anhedonia Significant weight change or change in appetite Insomnia or hypersomnia Psychomotor agitation or retardation Fatigue or loss of energy Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt Decreased ability to concentrate or indecisiveness Thoughts of death or suicidal ideationThere has never been a manic, hypomanic, or mixed episode. Option: C . Schizotypal disorder- A schizotypal personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder . It usually manifests with eccentric behavior , and affected individuals have odd beliefs or magical thinking that are inconsistent with cultural norms. This woman's social anxiety, inappropriate affect, and lack of close friends are also common features of this disorder. Option: D . Delusional disorder- Delusional disorder is a type of psychotic disorder. Its main symptom is the presence of one or more delusions. A delusion is an unshakable belief in something that's untrue. The belief isn't a part of the person's culture or subculture, and almost everyone else knows this belief to be false.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male developed a loss of interest to achieve goals under the poverty of speech for the past year. The patient was started on antipsychotics but showed the worst prognosis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Simple schizophrenia Simple schizophrenia is characterized by the presence of only negative symptoms and the worst prognosis . Negative symptoms include avolition, alogia, anhedonia, attention deficit, and asocial .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. In residual schizophrenia, the patient shows remission of delusions and hallucinations but the negative symptoms usually persist. Option: C . Catatonic schizophrenia involves features of catatonia like mutism, stupor, waxy flexibility, etc. It shows a better prognosis. Option: D. Paranoid schizophrenia is the most common It mainly has positive symptoms and rarely shows negative symptoms. It is characterized by late onset and a better prognosis .

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency after his mother found him locked in his room stammering about a government conspiracy to brainwash him in subterranean tunnels 6 months ago when he also stopped attending classes and was subsequently suspended from college. His father was diagnosed with schizophrenia at the age of 25 years. Which of the following is a favorable prognostic factor for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute onset of symptoms The acute onset of symptoms in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia is associated with a more favorable long-term prognosis than a gradual onset.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: B. Male sex is a negative prognostic factor in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia. Option: C. Positive family history is a negative prognostic factor in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia. This patient's father had schizophrenia, putting him at risk for a less favorable course of the disease. Option: D. The age of onset correlates with long-term outcomes in patients diagnosed with schizophrenia. Older age at the time of disease onset pretends a more favorable prognosis . This patient is only , which is rather associated with a poor prognosis.

questions.text: A PSM resident was doing a project on the epidemiology of Schizophrenia and noted the following points. Which of the following statements is/are false? Schizophrenia is equally prevalent in men and women but onset is earlier in men than in women. The outcome for male schizophrenia patients is better than for females. Persons with schizophrenia have a higher mortality rate from accidents and natural causes than the general population Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only 2 The outcome for male schizophrenia patients is better than for females is not true. Outcome for female schizophrenia patients is better.

Highyeild:

Gender and Age - Schizophrenia is equally prevalent in men and women . However, onset is earlier in men than in women. The peak ages of onset are 10 to 25 years for men and 25 to 35 years for women. Unlike men, women display a bimodal age distribution , with a second peak occurring in middle age. In general, the outcome for female schizophrenia patients is better than that for male schizophrenia patients. Persons with schizophrenia have a higher mortality rate from accidents and natural causes than the general population. Substance abuse is common in schizophrenia and has an increased prevalence of abuse of common street drugs . Infection and Birth - Studies have pointed to gestational and birth complications, exposure to influenza epidemics, maternal starvation during pregnancy, Rhesus factor incompatibility, and an excess of winter births in the etiology of schizophrenia. The nature of these factors suggests a neurodevelopmental pathological process .

Random:

Explanation for Other Points:- Point 1- Schizophrenia is equally prevalent in men and women but onset is earlier in men than in women is a true statement therefore, is not the answer. Point 3- Persons with schizophrenia have a higher mortality rate from accidents and natural causes than the general population.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was brought to the hospital by his wife saying that he doesn’t sleep at night but sits staring at a wall and says his master is sitting there and giving him commands. He doesn’t talk well with her or his parents. She says he scolds her and blames she is trying to harm him. The biochemical changes seen in this patient are given below. Match them correctly. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1=b, 2=a, 3=d, 4=c Option A. Dopamine - schizophrenia results from too much dopaminergic activity . Excessive dopamine release in patients with schizophrenia has been linked to the severity of positive psychotic symptoms . Option B. Serotonin - Serotonin is a cause of both positive and negative symptoms in schizophrenia. Option C. Norepinephrine . Anhedonia has long been noted to be a prominent feature of schizophrenia. A selective neuronal degeneration within the norepinephrine reward neural system could account for this aspect of schizophrenic symptomatology. Option D. GABA - The inhibitory amino acid neurotransmitter γ-amino butyric acid (GABA) has been implicated in the pathophysiology of schizophrenia based on the finding that some patients with schizophrenia have a loss of GABAergic neurons in the hippocampus . GABA has a regulatory effect on dopamine activity, and the loss of inhibitory GABAergic neurons could lead to the hyperactivity of dopaminergic neurons.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman was brought to the hospital by her husband as she states that she can see and talk to Devi for 3-4 days who keep guiding her to help others. She doesn’t talk much with her children or take care of them for a few months, doesn’t recognize her husband, and says that her husband died 8 months ago. True statements about the neuropathology of this patient are:- CT scans of these patients show lateral and third ventricular enlargement and some reduction in cortical volume. There is reduced symmetry in several brain areas in patients with this disorder, including the temporal, frontal, and occipital lobes. The medial dorsal nucleus of the thalamus, which has reciprocal connections with the prefrontal cortex, has been reported to contain a reduced number of neurons. Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, and 3 The given case is that of Schizophrenia . Neuropathology according to various studies shows: Option A. Cerebral Ventricles . Computed tomography (CT) scans of patients with schizophrenia have consistently shown lateral and third ventricular enlargement and some reduction in cortical volume . Reduced volumes of cortical gray matter have been demonstrated during the earliest stages of the disease. Option B. Reduced Symmetry . There is a reduced symmetry in several brain areas in schizophrenia, including the temporal, frontal, and occipital lobes . Option C. Thalamus . Some studies of the thalamus show evidence of volume shrinkage or neuronal loss , in particular the medial dorsal nucleus of the thalamus , subnuclei . Option D. Basal Ganglia and Cerebellum . Many patients with schizophrenia show odd movements, even in the absence of medication-induced movement disorders (e.g., tardive dyskinesia). The odd movements can include an awkward gait , facial grimacing, and stereotypies. The movement disorders involving the basal ganglia (e.g., Huntington’s disease, Parkinson’s disease) are most commonly associated with psychosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with symptoms of talking to herself, hearing voices and suicidal attempts was diagnosed with Schizophrenia, and was started on antipsychotics. The patient on treatment after 3 weeks is said to be less responsive and less interactive. The reason can be
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above Option: A. Some cases of Schizophrenia on treatment with antipsychotics (usually typical) will have an increase in the negative symptoms due to deterioration of the mesocortical pathway . Option: B. Pseudo-Parkinsonism is the most common side effect of antipsychotic Such patients show reduced responsiveness and an increase in negative symptoms . Option: C. Patients with Schizophrenia may develop mood disorders like depression which lead to the above-mentioned scenario.
